When calculated in the common factorization approach at any finite order in perturbation theory, this distribution diverges as Qr — 0, signaling that infrared singularities associated with Q; — 0 have not been properly iso- lated and regulated. These singularities are associated with soft and collinear radiation from initial-state partons shown by the diagrams in Figs. [I] (b), (d), and (i). A generalized factorization approach that correctly describes the small-Qr region was developed by Collins, Soper, and Sterman (CSS) and applied to photon pair produc- tion rie . In this approach the hadronic cross section is expressed as an integral over the transverse coordinate (impact parameter). The integrable singular functions present in the finite-order differential distribution as Qr — 0 are resummed, to all orders in the strong coupling a,, into a Sudakov exponent, and a well-behaved cross section is obtained for all Qr values.
